bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jesse Daniel Ames, December 9, 1929

div1.p: Kean does not believe that Roger Ames had yellow fever, in 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jesse Daniel Ames, December 9, 1929
div1.opener:
COPY
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON
Washington, D. C.
December 9, 1929
Mrs. Roger Post Ames
Commission on Interracial Cooperation
409 Palmer Building
Atlanta, Georgia
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I have your letter of 4 December and am glad to reply to it
but fear that I cannot shed any light on the question of Dr. Ames's
alleged attack of yellow fever. If he did in fact have an attack of
yellow fever in Cuba it is certainly extraordinary that I should not
have known of it, but as you know, I had never heard of it until you
mentioned it in your letter some little time ago. It was a generally
accepted fact that he was an immune, and the only mention which Major
Walter Reed makes of him in his published articles on the work of the
Board he speaks of him as an immune. It is my recollection that he
was selected to be in charge of the personnel of Camp Lazear on that
account. I left Havana on 30 January, 1901 to go to Washington for
my examination for promotion. I was absent only three weeks and it
was, I now understand, during this period that he was sick for a few
days in the hospital at Camp Columbia. If the records state that this
sickness was yellow fever I believe it must be a clerical error or I
would have heard of it on my return. I am perfectly certain that it
was not one of the experimental cases of yellow fever, and if a case
of yellow fever not experimental had originated in the camp, I am sure
I would have heard of it. I agree with what General Ireland told you
that the period of sickness in the hospital was entirely too short for
even a mild case. All cases that I have ever seen where there was no
doubt about the diagnosis were in the hospital more than a week, and were
followed by a long period of weakness and depression; I am sure it was
so in my case.

If you want to get an official record of this illness of Dr.
Ames's in February you will have to get it by applying to the Adjutant
General. The Surgeon General's Office does not, as you would suppose,
keep the sick and wounded cards after he had tabulated them and made
his annual report. Then the original records are transferred to the
Adjutant General's Office for file, and he is the only official in the
War Department who is authorized to give out information concerning
them.
Wishing you a Merry Christmas, I am

closer.signed:
(Signed) J. R. Kean
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.
